items.title: Author Craig Silvey not cooperating with authorities after arrest, court told
items.description: One of Australia's most renowned authors, Craig Silvey, faces court after he allegedly distributed child exploitation material.

items.title: Neo-Nazi group says it will disband due to proposed hate speech laws
items.description: In a statement posted to Telegram, the group announced the closure of the National Socialist Network would also spell the end of "co-projects" White Australia, the European Australian Movement and the White Australia Party.

items.title: James Webb telescope reveals how black holes starved early galaxies

featured_image.name: These 'impossible' galaxies are breaking the Universe as we know it

items.description:
A series of discoveries announced this week are reshaping astronomers' understanding of the early universe, revealing unexpected heat, unusual galaxy types, and cosmic structures that defy existing models of how the first galaxies formed and evolved.

Research published January 12 in Nature Astronomy describes a massive galaxy that "lived fast and died young" after its supermassive black hole slowly starved it of the cold gas needed to form new stars. Meanwhile, separate findings presented at the 247th meeting of the American Astronomical Society in Phoenix show galaxy clusters far hotter than predicted and objects so strange that scientists are comparing them to the platypus.[1][2][3]

items.title: Asian currencies slide after Trump threatens Iran trade tariffs

featured_image.name: President Trump Spends Weekend At Mar-a-Lago In Palm Beach, Florida

items.description:
Asian currencies weakened broadly on Tuesday as traders grappled with fresh tariff warnings from President Donald Trump targeting countries that do business with Iran, while rising oil prices and concerns over the Federal Reserve's independence added to regional market pressures.

The Japanese yen fell to a one-year low against the dollar, while the Indian rupee and South Korean won also declined, according to Investing.com [1]. The selloff came after Trump announced Monday that any country doing business with Iran would face a 25% tariff on U.S. trade, escalating economic pressure as anti-government protests spread across the Middle Eastern nation.

items.title: Over 200 U.S. scientists condemn Trump's Greenland acquisition push

featured_image.name: White House Draws Up Plans to Acquire Greenland as Trump ...

items.description:
President Donald Trump's renewed push to bring Greenland under American control has drawn fierce opposition from European allies and a coordinated rebuke from more than 200 U.S. scientists, even as mining experts say the island's mineral wealth may be far more difficult to access than the administration suggests.

"We are going to do something on Greenland whether they like it or not," Trump declared on Friday during a White House meeting with oil executives[1][2]. "If we don't do it the easy way, we're going to do it the hard way."

The remarks, coming days after U.S. military forces removed Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro on January 3, have alarmed European leaders and prompted Danish Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen to declare that her country faces a "decisive moment" in its diplomatic struggle with Washington[3][4].

items.title: Starlink helps some Iranians bypass internet blackout

featured_image.name: Plan-S launches four new Connecta IoT satellites with SpaceX

items.description:
Some Iranians are maintaining access to the outside world through Elon Musk's Starlink satellite internet service despite a sweeping communications blackout imposed by authorities amid deadly crackdowns on nationwide protests, three people inside the country told Reuters [1][2].

The satellite service, which beams internet directly from thousands of low-Earth orbit satellites operated by SpaceX, continues to function in some parts of Iran even though authorities have banned the technology and imposed severe penalties on users [1][3].

items.title: Adelaide Writers' Week cancelled after week of escalating controversy
items.description: The remaining members of the Adelaide Festival board will step down and this year's Writers' Week event has been cancelled, after days of furore regarding the decision to cancel a scheduled appearance by Palestinian-Australian author Randa Abdel-Fattah.

items.title: Retired navy captain Mark Kelly sues the Pentagon over free speech
items.description: The US Democratic senator alleges the president and defense secretary are trying to intimidate him into silence for comments he made in a video calling on serving troops to defy illegal orders.

items.title: Woman behind crepe attack on chief minister sentenced in court
items.description: The woman who assaulted a former Northern Territory chief minister with a cream crepe is sentenced to 12 months imprisonment, fully suspended.

items.title: Iran using 'military-grade' jamming to take down Musk's Starlink
items.description: Human rights groups estimate more than 500 people have been killed and more than 10,600 arrested in the ongoing protests.

items.title: The sort of world in which Rudd has lived most of his career is now gone
items.description: One month after Kevin Rudd leaves his post as Australia's ambassador to Washington, Donald Trump will make his first presidential visit to China in almost 10 years.

items.title: 'I do my best to settle my conscience': SA premier becomes emotional at press conference
items.description: Peter Malinauskas becomes tearful during a media conference where he faces extensive questions about the crisis surrounding Adelaide Writers' Week and allegations of homophobia against Adelaide United made by former player Josh Cavallo.

items.title: Russia strikes Ukraine power grid, cutting electricity to 7 regions

featured_image.name: Kyiv Power Outage Continues After Russian Attacks

items.description:
Russian forces struck Ukraine's energy infrastructure overnight on Monday, cutting power to seven regions as the country endures its fourth wartime winter under relentless bombardment. The attack left consumers in Odesa, Zhytomyr, Sumy, Kharkiv, Donetsk, Dnipropetrovsk, and Chernihiv without electricity, according to Ukraine's Ministry of Energy[1][2].

Emergency blackouts were imposed in Kyiv and the surrounding region, as well as in Odesa, Kharkiv, and Donetsk oblasts. Authorities said a gradual transition from emergency restrictions to scheduled hourly shutdowns was underway in the capital[1].

The overnight assault extends a devastating week of Russian strikes targeting Ukraine's power grid. Prime Minister Yulia Svyrydenko said not a single day had passed this week without attacks on energy facilities, with 44 strikes recorded in total[3][4].

items.title: Zelensky warns of imminent Russian strike as Kyiv struggles to restore heat

featured_image.name: Kyiv Power Outage Continues After Russian Attacks

items.description:
Emergency crews worked around the clock on Monday to restore heating and electricity to Kyiv residents more than three days after devastating Russian attacks on energy infrastructure, as President Volodymyr Zelensky warned that another large-scale assault could be imminent.

About 800 residential buildings in the Ukrainian capital remained without heating as of January 12, according to Mayor Vitali Klitschko[1], down from approximately 6,000 buildings that lost heat following a massive overnight assault on January 9 that killed at least four people and injured 25 others[2]. Deputy Prime Minister Oleksiy Kuleba reported that 85% of Kyiv's residential buildings have had heating restored[3][4].

"There is intelligence information. The Russians are preparing a new massive strike," Zelensky said in his evening video address. "Drones to exhaust air defense systems and missiles. They want to take advantage of the cold. The strike may occur in the coming days."[3][5]

items.title: China, India cut coal power together for first time since 1970s
items.description:
For the first time in more than half a century, coal-fired power generation declined simultaneously in China and India last year, according to new analysis, marking what researchers call a "historic moment" in the global energy transition.

The concurrent reduction in coal-generated electricity in the world's two largest coal-consuming nations had not occurred since 1973, according to the Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air (CREA), a Helsinki-based think tank. The analysis, commissioned by the UK climate news platform Carbon Brief, found that coal power generation in India fell by 3% in 2025, while China saw a 1.6% decline.[1][2][3]

items.title: European nations declare 'Greenland belongs to its people' after Trump threats

featured_image.name: European leaders push back over Trump's renewed Greenland ...

items.description:
The world's largest island has become a flashpoint in an escalating geopolitical contest, as its melting ice sheet reveals both scientific warnings about climate change and vast mineral wealth coveted by global powers.

President Donald Trump's continued insistence that the United States will acquire Greenland "one way or the other" has thrust the sparsely populated Danish territory into the center of international tensions, even as researchers race to understand how its ice loss will reshape coastlines worldwide.[1][2]

items.title: Cornell study finds 70-year metal strength rule reverses at supersonic speeds

featured_image.name: Supersonic shock tests reveal that metals weaken under ...

items.description:
For more than seven decades, the Hall-Petch effect has guided engineers in strengthening metals: make the grains smaller, and the metal gets harder. But a new study from Cornell University has upended that foundational principle, revealing that at extreme speeds, smaller-grained metals actually become weaker.

The research, published January 12, 2026 in Physical Review Letters, found that when copper is deformed at supersonic velocities, the long-held relationship between grain size and strength reverses entirely[1][2].

items.title: Mexico's Sheinbaum says Trump call ruled out US military action

featured_image.name: Mexican president tells Trump that US intervention against cartels is 'unnecessary'

items.description:
U.S. Secretary of State Marco Rubio spoke with Mexican Foreign Minister Juan Ramon de la Fuente on January 11, 2026, in a call focused on dismantling drug trafficking networks and stopping the flow of fentanyl across the border. The conversation came days after President Donald Trump threatened to launch ground operations against Mexican cartels, remarks that have heightened tensions between the neighboring nations.[1][2]

The call was initiated at the instruction of Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum, who on Friday directed de la Fuente to engage with U.S. officials to "strengthen coordination" under the existing bilateral security agreement.[3][4]

items.title: Three people rescued from central Queensland flood as ex-Cyclone Koji moves west
items.description: A clean-up is under way at Clermont, which remains cut off by floodwaters, as already-saturated western communities are being warned of possible heavy rains.

items.title: Live: Threat of more severe weather in Victoria as 179 homes lost to blazes
items.description: Firefighters continue to battle fires across the state after the grim news that a person had been found dead and at least 400,000 hectares have been burnt. Follow live.

items.title: President Trump Announces U.S. Military Airstrike in Venezuela
items.description: President Trump states the U.S. military conducted its first known airstrike inside Venezuela targeting a dock where drugs were allegedly loaded onto boats[1][2][4].

items.title: Trump Meets Netanyahu at Mar-a-Lago for Gaza Ceasefire Phase Two Talks
items.description: President Trump met with Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to discuss advancing phase two of the Gaza ceasefire, including reconstruction and responses to Iran[1][4].

items.title: Feds Launch Massive Taxpayer Fraud Probe in Minnesota After Viral Video
items.description: Federal agencies including DHS, FBI, and ICE investigate $110 million in suspected fraud at Minnesota child care centers following a viral YouTube video[3].

items.title: Americans Express Widespread Opposition to AI Data Centers
items.description: Public backlash against AI infrastructure data centers grows, with protests and demands for bans influencing Democratic Party strategies for future elections[3].

items.title: Elon Musk's Humanoid Robot Vision: China Poised to Lead Production
items.description: China prioritizes humanoid robots in tech race with U.S., ramping up production while warning of industry bubble and potential bottlenecks[3].

items.title: Trump-Putin Call Amid Ukraine-Russia Tensions Over Peace Plan
items.description: President Trump spoke with Putin amid ongoing Ukraine conflict, with Russia reevaluating peace plan tenets after Ukrainian denials[1].

items.title: Democratic Gubernatorial Candidates in Wisconsin Focus on Inflation and Trump
items.description: Seven Democrats vying for Wisconsin governor blame economic issues on Trump and emphasize affordability ahead of 2026 primary[3].
